Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is developing, disseminating, and maintaining activities that broadly promote and disseminate the impact and outcomes of the Centers supported through the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Program. The goal is to inform stakeholders of the resources and services offered through the coalition of ATE centers. The overall outcome is a community that makes informed decisions and takes informed actions to promote and support technician education and a competitive workforce in the United States. The project objectives include: print publications, an interactive website, branded displays, and joint ATE Center exhibits at both national and regional meetings. These activities are: increasing decision makers' and influencers' knowledge of ATE program activities and accomplishments; raising other educators' awareness of ATE resources and services; cultivating new partnerships to advance initiatives important to the nation's technological workforce and STEM education; and creating a distinct and national brand for the advanced technological education centers and projects that receive support from the National Science Foundation. The broader impacts of the project are significant. The website, print publications, and joint center exhibits emphasize the range of disciplines supported by the centers. These efforts support the entire ATE community and further disseminate the program outcomes to new audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation is one of the strongest supporters of Community College technician education programs in the United States. But this fact is not very well known.

 

This project, ATE Collaborative Impact, was designed to dramatically increase the awareness in the public and private sectors, of the value and impact of the Advanced Technological Education program. The method used was to create a high quality print publication whose images, graphics and content conveyed not only the intellectual merit of these unique technician education programs but also their broad impact on a population of students and adults who are helping our advanced technology industries maintain a competitive edge.

 

Two editions of the Impact booklet, 2014 and 2016 were designed and created with a collaborative of 42 centers. A companion website supports the publication, www.atecenters.org. It is designed to keep the information up to date and to make the work broadly accessible. Over 10,000 visitors accessed the site in the final year of the project.

 

The publications also feature our country’s leaders who acknowledge the value of the program. Studies of the program reveal it significantly reaches women and underrepresented populations to help them achieve their education and career goals.

 

In addition to the print and web formats, the project created a series of 23 web seminars. Co-produced with the Centers Collaborative for Technical Assistance, these live, web-broadcast seminars enrolled over 2,500 people. They took action after the seminars by modifying their courses, planning their new curriculum, interacting more with industry and creating new ideas to continue the advance of technological education.

 

Between the two editions, almost 20,000 copies of ATE Centers Impact were distributed in its print form. Now faculty, college administrators, workforce developers, students and the general public have a unique entry point into the world of advanced technological impact and the impact it can make on the lives and careers of our students.

Modified by: Michael L Lesiecki
